snippet.textDisplay:
You have very bright and diverse speech. Sometimes it's overloaded with the emotional charge.
It's hard to concentrate on the meaning of the words. Also the viewers are deprived of the opportunity to form their own emotional response to the essay. You feed your own emotions to them. It might be bad for the idea you're broadcasting, although your fans might like it. An example:


8:14
"Which... hold up. OK. So you're saying that you can break the canon in order to maintain effective storytelling. Okay. COOL.Very cool. But that's even though you're spending MMILLIIOONNS OF DOLLARS on pre-production to develop this alien world, which you might end up ignoring in order to better develop a story THAT YOU HAVEN'T WRITTEN YET?? <inaudible> WHAT??!"


It's all about you here. You're expressing your own feelings, instead of letting viewers to discover and combine the facts and feel something by themselves. It's common across your videos and sometimes it's a slight drag. It won't stop me or other people from enjoying the quality content which you produce, but it's just not necessary! Peace


P.S. Listening to examples of music with someone's SPEAKING OVER THEM is painful... 8:54
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
"It's filled with all these none english sounds like ejectives, affricatives and glottal stops"
You are aware that one of the glottal sounds in the IPA is "h" which turns up a whole lot in English, and affricatives are literally only a normal fricative (Something Like the s in ein or sh in shoot) with a d or a t in Front of them , for example when you say George , the dsh sound at the start is an affricate. Don't pretend like you know linguistics, when you don't know shit. Na'vii doesn't even come close to elvish, and even that is heavily based in english and germanic languages.
snippet.textOriginal:
"It's filled with all these none english sounds like ejectives, affricatives and glottal stops"
You are aware that one of the glottal sounds in the IPA is "h" which turns up a whole lot in English, and affricatives are literally only a normal fricative (Something Like the s in ein or sh in shoot) with a d or a t in Front of them , for example when you say George , the dsh sound at the start is an affricate. Don't pretend like you know linguistics, when you don't know shit. Na'vii doesn't even come close to elvish, and even that is heavily based in english and germanic languages.

snippet.textDisplay:
^^ I read "iconic" and not "ironic" and immediately thought, why? Wasn't the Avatar OST pretty standard James Horner doodle?
Then I recognized: Oh, no, it's IRONIC.... mhm, wasn't the Avatar OST pretty standard James Horner doodle? Why should it be ironic? There certainly wasn't much effort involved...

I was very wrong.

I think the reason for that is cocaine. It turns rich people into megalomaniacs.

snippet.textDisplay:
So, you can learn the language.. There are websites out there dedicated to teaching you the language. There are also Youtube videos that break down the individual sounds and teach basic words so you could actually have a conversation.

Apparently there are people who meet up at conventions who's only form of common communication is the Na'vi language. They're from completely different countries and natively speak completely different languages, but they both know Na'vi, so they can talk to each other just fine.


Which I think is kind of neat.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Man, when I watched Avatar the first time, I didn't care that much about music, not like I do now. but I will never be able to watch that Film again, without feeling like I'm being cheated on. This could have been like the most amazing soundtrack ina movie ever. Revolutionising film-music... Why does there even have to be an 19th century orchestra in a blockbuster, why not do something completely new. That would have been groundbreaking and highly influential. I don't like it, such a wasted chance!
snippet.textOriginal: Man, when I watched Avatar the first time, I didn't care that much about music, not like I do now. but I will never be able to watch that Film again, without feeling like I'm being cheated on. This could have been like the most amazing soundtrack ina movie ever. Revolutionising film-music... Why does there even have to be an 19th century orchestra in a blockbuster, why not do something completely new. That would have been groundbreaking and highly influential. I don't like it, such a wasted chance!

snippet.textDisplay: I’m somewhat glad they didn’t use the traditional music of the small ethnic groups mentioned. It just feels like another example of cultural appropriation: taking (probably without asking) from some minority and then using their music which is part of their culture for profit (probably without quoting and/or paying them). It is a freaking western Hollywood movie, use western Hollywood music.
snippet.textOriginal: I’m somewhat glad they didn’t use the traditional music of the small ethnic groups mentioned. It just feels like another example of cultural appropriation: taking (probably without asking) from some minority and then using their music which is part of their culture for profit (probably without quoting and/or paying them). It is a freaking western Hollywood movie, use western Hollywood music.

snippet.textDisplay:
If this movie is a lot like Pocahontas, Ferngully, the Lorax, etc. then... does that mean that Pocahontas, Ferngully, the Lorax and so on are all... basically the same thing? Or is Avatar just the... like, intersection of all these other movies - but blue?
Edit: Not surprisingly, the Lament was my favourite piece in the whole soundtrack. Oh, to imagine the whole film having music like that...
snippet.textOriginal:
If this movie is a lot like Pocahontas, Ferngully, the Lorax, etc. then... does that mean that Pocahontas, Ferngully, the Lorax and so on are all... basically the same thing? Or is Avatar just the... like, intersection of all these other movies - but blue?
Edit: Not surprisingly, the Lament was my favourite piece in the whole soundtrack. Oh, to imagine the whole film having music like that...

snippet.textDisplay: I think your critic is irrelevant, cause yes he did throw out a whole lot of money by just getting ride of the "alien" music, but It's a movie, and Cameron is a story teller, if something does not fit his vision of the story he is trying to tell,well he is in ull right of just getting rid of it. Cameron is one of the most exigent director in Hollywood, and it's a pain in the ass working with him, but he knows what his doing. And yes he tries to make his movie accessible to everyone, where is that a problem ? And something else i find exaggerated, is that yeah sure they had a ton of music idea, but like music is extradiegetic (at least for the most part of the movie) as the camera, the audience, actually everything that is here to show the story. It's a media, a support to tell a story, but if he really wanted to make it "alien" then he would've probably changed the way of filming, that is pretty western, or the timing, or the story timeline by making it non linear (like first contact, which isn't accessible to everyone) the movie is only a window to show us something. But i do agree it is a bit ironic, but Cameron doesn't do this for the money, he does this because he loves it, you just have to watch the making of the abyss to understand that this man's whole life is about making not only movies, but making great movie for everyone to watch.
snippet.textOriginal: I think your critic is irrelevant, cause yes he did throw out a whole lot of money by just getting ride of the "alien" music, but It's a movie, and Cameron is a story teller, if something does not fit his vision of the story he is trying to tell,well he is in ull right of just getting rid of it. Cameron is one of the most exigent director in Hollywood, and it's a pain in the ass working with him, but he knows what his doing. And yes he tries to make his movie accessible to everyone, where is that a problem ? And something else i find exaggerated, is that yeah sure they had a ton of music idea, but like music is extradiegetic (at least for the most part of the movie) as the camera, the audience, actually everything that is here to show the story. It's a media, a support to tell a story, but if he really wanted to make it "alien" then he would've probably changed the way of filming, that is pretty western, or the timing, or the story timeline by making it non linear (like first contact, which isn't accessible to everyone) the movie is only a window to show us something. But i do agree it is a bit ironic, but Cameron doesn't do this for the money, he does this because he loves it, you just have to watch the making of the abyss to understand that this man's whole life is about making not only movies, but making great movie for everyone to watch.

snippet.textDisplay:
I saw it once. It was OK, but as many, many people have pointed out, Avatar is just Dances With Wolves, but has giant blue kitty people instead of Native Americans.
And Cameron is making, not one, but FOUR sequels, more than a decade after the original movie was released.
Imagine FOUR sequels to Dances With Wolves. With Kevin Costner (who Jake is a clone of, by the way, in case you didn't notice).

snippet.textDisplay:
This is Cameron in a nutshell,yeah.

If you're wondering why Robert Rodriguez took over from Cameron as Director for Alita, this would encapsulate it.
Cameron, as much as I love his work, is such a notoriously finnicky perfectionist to work with, he can render any production a hell to work on.
I mean, they say HIS version of Alita would have been over 7 hours long, but let's face it, the way he approached it, the project would never have seen completion to begin with.

Cameron wanted to make Alita since BEFORE Avatar, but waited it out cause he didn't think they had the tech yet to do it justice.
Which in a way I highly respect. As a big Alita fan I vastly prefered the slow and steady approach and respect for the source material rather than a rush job prone to fail.
But Cameron announced Alita back in 2003, already stating he "had the perfect actress for the role", which couldn't have been Rosa since she only got into acting around 2010.
Point being, with Cameron spending over a decade getting ready to make the project, his intended casting probably had already gotten a bit too old for the role.
Again, not complaining. Rosa was perfect for the role herself and while I don't think the original casting was ever made public, considering the often recurring names in the early 2000's, maybe it's a blessing that didn't happen.

TLDR: James Cameron is a very difficult man to work with.
snippet.textOriginal:
This is Cameron in a nutshell,yeah.

If you're wondering why Robert Rodriguez took over from Cameron as Director for Alita, this would encapsulate it.
Cameron, as much as I love his work, is such a notoriously finnicky perfectionist to work with, he can render any production a hell to work on.
I mean, they say HIS version of Alita would have been over 7 hours long, but let's face it, the way he approached it, the project would never have seen completion to begin with.

Cameron wanted to make Alita since BEFORE Avatar, but waited it out cause he didn't think they had the tech yet to do it justice.
Which in a way I highly respect. As a big Alita fan I vastly prefered the slow and steady approach and respect for the source material rather than a rush job prone to fail.
But Cameron announced Alita back in 2003, already stating he "had the perfect actress for the role", which couldn't have been Rosa since she only got into acting around 2010.
Point being, with Cameron spending over a decade getting ready to make the project, his intended casting probably had already gotten a bit too old for the role.
Again, not complaining. Rosa was perfect for the role herself and while I don't think the original casting was ever made public, considering the often recurring names in the early 2000's, maybe it's a blessing that didn't happen.

TLDR: James Cameron is a very difficult man to work with.

English has fricatives. F, th. A glottal stop is that hiccup in ‘uh-oh’. And ejectives are used in beat-boxing.

—a conlanger

snippet.textDisplay:
I avoided watching your video for days because I thought it said "most iConic soundtrack of all time", witch is something I vehemently disagree with, and though I'm usually very open, right now with the world in a tailspin, I don't want the aggravation. Now that I've realized that it's just my eyes that are garbage, I'll deign to watch your little vignette while enjoying myself.

Edit:
I am aggravated. I. Am. Very... AGGRAVATED!!!

Why the fuuuuuuckkk didn't Cameron show some God damn respect for his own vision and the composer who has never written a bad score in his life!? The composer who is now dead, with his Magnum Opus unfinished and replaced with a committee composed, paint-by-the-numbers Lion King simulacrum 😡🔥😡

If anyone has access to the original demos, speak up now!

Edit No. 2:
Come to think of it, though: James Horner's massive success with his 'Titanic' score is probably what killed potentially good or at least interesting film music happening for the next decade, ultimately leaving up to the money-hungry music decisions that prevented his original vision from happening. There's some poetic justice in that. Imagine if Philip Glass' "Kundun" -score had won instead? Or Elliot Smith's song in the song category.

Eh, Titanic would still have sold like crazy

Edit:

Why the fuuuuuuckkk didn't Cameron show some God damn respect for his own vision and the composer who has never written a bad score in his life!? The composer who is now dead, with his Magnum Opus unfinished and replaced with a committee composed, paint-by-the-numbers Lion King simulacrum 😡🔥😡 

If anyone has access to the original demos, speak up now!

Edit No. 2:
Come to think of it, though: James Horner's massive success with his 'Titanic' score is probably what killed potentially good or at least interesting film music happening for the next decade, ultimately leaving up to the money-hungry music  decisions that prevented his original vision from happening. There's some poetic justice in that. Imagine if Philip Glass' "Kundun" -score had won instead? Or Elliot Smith's song in the song category. 

Eh, Titanic would still have sold like crazy

snippet.textDisplay:
1:32 have that book
never bought it, just have it
I always ADORED this film,even learnt a bit of the language (which I still remember now)
And I realise that I loved it so much because of how much work went into it, the little details, the language, how they made the film, cinematography, behind the scenes. And also the fandom, which is literally the most loving and accepting one (they even to meet-ups and do activities like visit locations with Avatar-related things, learn the language, watch the film). Also all those moments with hints of the musical effort the pair went to were my favourite, and I always wished there was more. it's sad to hear we never got that beautiful blend of sound, especially since I resonate with them so much.
snippet.textOriginal:
1:32  have that book
never bought it, just have it
I always ADORED this film,even learnt a bit of the language (which I still remember now)
And I realise that I loved it so much because of how much work went into it, the little details, the language, how they made the film, cinematography, behind the scenes. And also the fandom, which is literally the most loving and accepting one (they even to meet-ups and do activities like visit locations with Avatar-related things, learn the language, watch the film). Also all those moments with hints of the musical effort the pair went to were my favourite, and I always wished there was more. it's sad to hear we never got that beautiful blend of sound, especially since I resonate with them so much.

snippet.textDisplay:
Correction: 6:51
The instrument on the left-hand side is called the 'Shakuhachi' I happen to play it. Its history is fascinating (see the jagged edge on the bottom? that's to make it a more effective bludgeoning weapon) However it can still access the full western scale and more. While only playing the main notes, DOES leave you with a pentatonic scale (starting on D, not C most the time) with half-covering the holes and note bending, you can play any piece of western music (there are actually MORE notes as they class different fingerings as different notes, and there's also microtonal stuff.
snippet.textOriginal:
Correction: 6:51
The instrument on the left-hand side is called the 'Shakuhachi' I happen to play it. Its history is fascinating (see the jagged edge on the bottom? that's to make it a more effective bludgeoning weapon) However it can still access the full western scale and more. While only playing the main notes, DOES leave you with a pentatonic scale (starting on D, not C most the time) with half-covering the holes and note bending, you can play any piece of western music (there are actually MORE notes as they class different fingerings as different notes, and there's also microtonal stuff.

snippet.textDisplay: Okay can we just finally dismiss that this was ever the most successful film in history? It was the highest grossing film without adjusting to inflation and you need to adjust for inflation. Gone With The Wind outperformed this film seventy years earlier and to this day continues to be the most successful film ever made. You need to adjust for inflation. If you don't then it's like saying the latest Japanese Godzilla film did super well because counting in yen makes a bigger number.
snippet.textOriginal: Okay can we just finally dismiss that this was ever the most successful film in history? It was the highest grossing film without adjusting to inflation and you need to adjust for inflation. Gone With The Wind outperformed this film seventy years earlier and to this day continues to be the most successful film ever made. You need to adjust for inflation. If you don't then it's like saying the latest Japanese Godzilla film did super well because counting in yen makes a bigger number.
